author: R Srikanth
text:
Authorities are confident of ensuring supply even if demand crosses the 3,000 MW mark

The unusually warm climate experienced by city residents and the relaxation of restriction and control measures for consumers who receive high tension power supply has resulted in a surge in electricity consumption when compared to the previous years.

However, the State government is confident of maintaining stabilised power supply even as they expect the demand to cross the 3,000 megawatts (MW) this summer.

A senior official of the Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation (Tangedco) said the electricity demand in the State crossed the 14,500 MW-mark in February with city demand touching 2,441 MW (February 29). This is not a regular phenomenon as the last time the demand touched 3,000 MW was in 2013 when the maximum electricity demand recorded was 3,027 MW on May 29.

According to data provided by Tangedco, electricity consumption in the city has been growing along with the number of domestic consumers over the past four years, even as demand has remained steady in the range between 2,500 and 3,000 MW in the city between April and July.

The only exception was 2015 when the consumption slightly decreased.

Tangedco officials are confident that several development measures carried out on the transmission front including construction of sub-stations, installation of new transformers and upgradation of electricity cable and pillar boxes would help in preventing low voltage or power cuts in the city.

A senior official said the commissioning of new substations at Guindy, Vyasarpadi, Sholinganallur, KITS Park in Sholinganallur and Manali had resulted in an improvement in stabilised supply.
title: Spike in power consumption continues
